subject: Security hardening: fix possible shell injection vulnerability
commit_message:
Security hardening: fix possible shell injection vulnerability

The glance/cmd/control.py file contains a possible shell injection
vulnerability:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/cmd/control.py#L134 .

Setting 'shell=True' here opens the possibility of shell injection
by setting server to something like '; rm -rf /'. This will cause
the command 'rm -rf /' to be run with the privileges of the user
that ran Glance.

The fix is to parameterize the input so that the command run here
can only be 'logger'.

subject: Configure write cache option of tgtd iscsi driver
commit_message:
Configure write cache option of tgtd iscsi driver

Cinder LVMiSCSI driver is using default value of write-cache parameter
of tgtd iscsi driver. In this setting, write I/O from guest instance is
cached on dirty cache of a host.(write-back mode)

In this case, data lost may be occurred if the host crashes before
flushing dirty cache. This may cause a lot of instances to lose
their data.

In order to avoid this issue, it is better to turn off the write cache.
(write-through mode)

This patch adds "iscsi_write_cache" parameter to configure a behavior of
write cache. The default value is "iscsi_write_cache=on".(write-back mode)

Closes-Bug: 1336568
DocImpact

subject: Allow to specify storage policy when uploading objects
commit_message:
Allow to specify storage policy when uploading objects

Client already supports -H/--header option when creating container
or uploading objects. This patch extends this option to support
Storage Policy.

e.g.,
    swift post con -H 'X-Storage-Policy:p1'
This creates one container 'con' with storage policy 'p1'.

    swift upload con obj -H 'X-Storage-Policy:p2'
This creates container 'con' with storage policy 'p2' and uploads
object 'obj' into it.

Also fixes segmented uploading to non-default storage policy container

When uploading large objects with segmentation to container with
non-default storage policy, there will be another 'xxx_segments'
container created, but with the default storage policy. This
results all the segments to be stored with the wrong policy.

This patch is for the Storage Policy feature, and also
compatible with old versions w/o Storage Policy support.

- Use cbbackup to do the backup

- Wait until bucket finishes creating
- Use cbrestore (which requires destination buckets to be manually

subject: Introduce Loadbalancer instance
commit_message:
Introduce Loadbalancer instance

This commit introduces loadbalancer instance into LBaaS API,
object model, driver interface, unit tests.
The purpose of LB instance:
1) envelope other main balancer resources such as vips and pools
That is needed to retain loadbalancer configuration as a tree
instead of a graph when multiple pools-vips relationship is
introduced. So Loadbalancer object becomes the root of the tree
instead of the Pool
2) Provide clear boundaries for loadbalancer configuration.
All objects that belong to one loadbalancer are deployed to one
device or agent and are handled with the same provider (driver)
3) Loadbalancer object becomes a 'mounting point' of attributes
associated with configuration such as provider, device, agent,
router.

The patch contains the following changes:
 - CRUD operations for loadbalancer resource
 - Autocreation of loadbalancer resource with the pool
 - Autodeletion of loadbalancer resource with vip or pool deletion
 (needed for API compatibility)
 - Corresponding changes in the driver API

Other changes:
 - provider attribute has moved to loadbalancer resource from the pool.
 E.g. provider attribute in the Pool object is deprecated, but returned
 for backward compatibility.
 - NiciraServicePlugin was fixed in order to preserve backward
compatibility of LBaaS API of Nicira Plugin

subject: Dnsmasq config files syntax issue when dhcp_domain is empty
commit_message:
Dnsmasq config files syntax issue when dhcp_domain is empty

When using dhcp-agent with the following property dhcp_domain=""
addn_hosts and host files genererated for Dnsmasq have wrong syntax
concerning hostname parameter (dot char at the end).

As described in RFC-952 the hostname grammar is as follows:
<hname> ::= <name>*["."<name>]
<name>  ::= <let>[*[<let-or-digit-or-hyphen>]<let-or-digit>]
Hence it can't be conclude with a dot char.

Dnsmasq process is waiting for a hostname (2nd parameter) in the
following files:
"addn_hosts" file contains:
   20.0.0.3 host-20-0-0-3. host-20-0-0-3
"host" file contains:
   fa:16:3e:bf:e1:e4,host-20-0-0-3.,20.0.0.3

With the patch you will get:
"addn_hosts":
   20.0.0.3 host-20-0-0-3 host-20-0-0-3
"host":
   fa:16:3e:bf:e1:e4,host-20-0-0-3,20.0.0.3

Closes-Bug: #1326256

'device_path' key in connection_info['data'].  However, if you
